bibl.title: Letter from C.C. Pierce to Henry Rose Carter, October 24, 1921

div1.p: Pierce writes that the Public Health Service seeks a high degree of excellence for all courses of instruction. Lecturers should be recognized leaders in their fields. Pierce asks Carter to prepare a statement on malaria and yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from C.C. Pierce to Henry Rose Carter, October 24, 1921
div1.opener:
File
Requisition
Lecture for P. H. Institute
(abstract of)
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
IN REPLYING
ADDRESS THE SURGEON GENERAL
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
BUREAU OF
THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
WASHINGTON
October 24, 1921.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
In planning the twenty-three Public Health Institutes, the
Public Health Service is eager to achieve a high degree of academic
excellence for all courses of instruction.

For several courses of each institute there will be avail-
able lecturers of national prominence who are familiar with the most
recent developments in their various fields. For other courses it
will be necessary to utilize local men who perhaps in some instances
have not had the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the latest
authoritative data in their fields. The Public Health Service, there-
fore, desires to make available for all lecturers a statement prepared
by a recognized leader in the field to contain material that will be
helpful to local men in the preparation of lectures.

The Service, therefore, would appreciate it very much if you
would prepare a very brief statement (one or two pages) on the subjects,
“Malaria and Yellow Fever” (which is the sixth lecture in the course on
The General Communicable Diseases), which would contain the following
data:
(a) Points to emphasize in a single lecture on the subject
(b) Mistakes to avoid: attempting to cover the subject in detail It is too big enough for one lecture - say 4 lectures
(c)The two most important books now available on the subject Rose: I. vol H. D. rk to P. all

(d) The three or four most recent and important magazine
article on the subject - know of none:
g. m. mag ----- & ----- May service put

May the Service hear from you at once as to whether you will
undertake the preparation of this statement? In writing, kindly say
whether it will be possible for you to send the statement within the
next ten days or two weeks.
By direction of the Surgeon General.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, CC Pierce
Assistant Surgeon General. HHM:EEG
Dr. H. R. Carter.
- 2 -
P. S. The course on The General Communicable Diseases at most of
the institutes includes the following lectures:
1. Typhoid Fever
2. Diphtheria and scarlet fever
3. Pneumonia and influenza
4. Other children's diseases
5. Poliomyelitis (in the South - Hookworm)
6. Malaria and yellow fever
